title: leo mckinstry schools reopening militant teaching unions
story: After the long summer holidays, it signies hope at the chance of fresh beginnings and excitement at the prospect of change.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesNext week, the new term will have greater meaning than ever for pupils, professionals and parents. At last, after an unprecedented lockdown of six months, all schools are due to re-open, representing a giant leap back towards normality. But the damage caused by the Coronavirus disruption has been severe.Many parents have been prevented from ing to work. Young people’s education has been badly undermined, especially because the quality of online learning has been so uneven. One study found that a fth of pupils had less than an hour’s instruction a day. Moreover, social activities and friendships – which are a vital part of growing up – have been heavily restricted.The exam chaos over the last fortnight was a fitting symbol of the vacuum created by the absence of proper schooling. No advanced society canwhen a vital sector like education is temporarily paralysed. That is why it is so important that the Government succeeds in its goal of seeing a fullto the classroom. As Boris Johnson put it at the weekend, “it is vital for pupils’ education. It is vital for their welfare. It’s vital for their physical and, indeed, mental well-being.”Given the Government’s mixed record on its management of the Covid crisis, this will be a big test. From the inadequate supply of protective gear to the botched imposition of quarantine rules, Ministers have got it badly wrong at times. They cannot afford another fiasco next week.But to do that, they will have to curtail the influence of militant teaching unions, which thrive in a climate of scare-mongering and grievance. Full of negativity, these hardened left-wing operators turn every pebble of dficulty into a giant boulder of obstruction. They are the abominable no men and women, the ultimate “can’t do” brigade.To overcome the unions’ capacity for trouble-making, reassurances about safety will be absolutely crucial. Most teachers are keen to go back to work, but they want to know schools will not be dangerous environments. That is why the recent upbeat advice from medical experts has been so welcome. It is clear from the Covid experience around the world that not only are children less likely to transmit the disease than any other group, but also that schools are safer than most other workplaces. Yesterday, the Deputy Chief Medical Officer Jenny Harries pointed out that a child is more likely to be involved in a traffic accident or die from flu than to be harmed by Coronavirus.That message was also spelt out by her boss Chris Whitty, who said on Sunday that the damage to health caused by a continued schools lockdown is potentially greater than the impact of Covid. “The balance of risk is very strongly in favour of children going to school,” he declared, adding the chances of catching the disease “are incredibly small.” In fact, there is now hard evidence to prove this. Although the vast majority of schools were closed since March, over one million pupils – such as the children of essential workers – went back to the classroom in June. Yet a comprehensive study by Public Health England showed that in the subsequent weeks until the end of term, just  children and  staff tested positive for Covid- – and nearly all these infections occurred outside the school. There were hardly any cases of children passing on the disease to each other, or to their teachers. Other research from around the world has come to the same conclusion.But none of this seems to matter to the teaching unions, eager to exploit anxiety in pursuit of their anti-Tory agenda. These are the organisations which for decades have blocked every major reform of the education system and have defended every outdated working practice. With depressing inevitability, they have continually put their own narrow interests before the wider needs of pupils. They want the respect due to trained professionals but they frequently display the rebellious spirit of the permanent agitators. “Strike action is a very powerful tool,” said Amanda Martin, the President of the ,-strong National Education Unionin an interview with the Communist Morning Star newspaper in , adding, “I’ve run demos and rallies and worked with trade councils to bring everyone out and that’s brilliant.”Led by the NEU, the unions have brought the same attitude to the Coronavirus crisis. Instead of looking for solutions, they have endlessly exaggerated problems. One Whitehall insider says of Dr Mary Bousted, the £,-a-year joint general secretary of the NEU, “it’s all about the union, to hell with the teachers who want to get back into the classroom – let alone the children.” A left-wing radical, Bousted jokes that the word “strike” was one of the first she learnt as a child. Hers is not the voice of co-operation and enterprise, so it is hardly surprising that the Government has struggled to get schools reopened.In June, a planned majorwas thwarted by the unions, dealing a severe blow to Gavin Williamson’s credibility. One left-wing website gushed that the continued shutdown was due “to the hard work of NEU branch secretaries and rank and file militants galvanising the members.” In the months since, an alliance of unions – including Bousted’s NEU and Unite led by the notorious Merseyside militant Len McCluskey – have fought a y battle against a swt re-opening. Central to this effort at sabotage was a vast -point checklist of detailed questions which the Department for Education was told it had to answer. Dubbed by critics “a wreckers’ charter”, the list included queries such as “will lidded bins with double bagging be available in every classroom”, “will dedicated space be available for any breastfeeding women to express milk” and “has behaviour policy been reviewed to acknowledge the increased level of trauma and anxiety experienced by pupils ” Some Tories complained that the union was playing politics. Robert Halfon, the chairman of the Education Select Committee was amazed at the warped priorities: “It is incredible that not one of these nit-picking questions asks the most important thing of all – what’s best for the kids ”Even as September approaches, the whining and resistance has not ceased. “The unions need to stand firm and protect their members,” argues socialist teacher Martin Powell-Davies. In the latest ruse, the public sector outfit UNISON not only wants its members to wear masks in the classroom – something for which there is no scientic evidence of any need – but also to have extra funding for deep cleaning. “Schools need more money to pay for specially trained cleaners, rather than relying on other staff who are busy enough already,” says Jon Richards, UNISON’s head of education. The moan about over-stretched budgets is a favourite of the union movement but it is an empty accusation. The Government is pouring an extra £. billion into education, while this summer it was announced that teachers’ pay is to go up by an average of . per cent, a bigger increase than any other public sector workers received.But that did nothing to stop the combination of whingeing and shroud-waving. The mentality of the hardliners was embodied in a recent statement from the NEU’s far left “Education Solidarity Network” which set out a series of demands to “make sure safety comes first.” Among them were: “smaller class sizes to allow adequate physical distancing” arrangements “for rotas and home learning to be produced in consultation with parents” “local risk assessments to include staggered outdoor breaks, sanitising, provision of transparent coverings to enable access to lip reading and facial expression” and “weekly onsite testing of staff”. Above all, the Network called for extra funding “to implement these measures.” If there were any question of a risk to safety, the union should “prepare for a national strike ballot.”That was so typical. This lot seem to feel more comfortable on the picket line than in the classroom. The Solidary Network might be seen as extreme, but its carping outlook runs right through the unionYesterday, the NEU’s joint general secretary was bleating on the airwaves about the risks of new Covid spikes: “Staff, parents and pupils are being sorely let down by the government because of a lack of a Plan B and of ensuring robust track and trace is in place throughout the country. We believe the Government is negligent in the extreme.” The charge of negligence might be applied with more force to the NEU, whose hostile stance has made thesuch an exhausting obstacle course. The militants cannot be allowed to prevail next week.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mum old baby yelled cant wake him up
story: The Brit, , discovered her four-month-old unconscious in the hotel room in Argyrades, Greece, as their holiday ended in tragedy. A nurse from England staying at the Labranda Sandy Beach Resort told of the heartbreaking battle to save him on Friday morning.She raced to the room to help after hearing the distraught mothers cries.The frontline nurse and the mums friend fought in vain for about  minutes to save the child.The locum nurse from Chippenham, Wiltshire, told Sun Online said: I did CPR with her friend.We heard help, help, phone the ambulance. I ran up the stairs because I didnt know where the shouting was coming from, I was like, where are you, where are you expecting to find someone had fallen over in the bathroom or something.She was like, its my baby, its my baby, I cant wake him up. Her friend was there doing CPR. We took over on the compressions, the two of us. But no-one was answering the hotel phone.Another guest staying at the hotel ran to reception to call for an ambulance but a doctor took about  minutes to arrive, the nurse added.The nurse said: By this point she had picked up the baby. There was no chance we were going to get him back, but we both had to try.She was running around the apartment block just shouting , My babys died, my babys died, help me, help me.We were like, put him down, put him back down well try again. When we got there I checked the pulse and there was nothing. He had been dead for a while, unfortunately.It was way too late, but like I said to my friend, what do you do, you have to give it a go.A doctor who arrived tried two lots of CPR before calling the police, she said.Medical Examiner Yiannis Aivatidis carried out a post-mortem examination after the babys death and ruled out choking from feeding.Dr Aivatidis also found there was no sign of bruising or injury to the body and declared the cause of death as sudden infant death syndrome.The mum and her pal, who are understood to be medics, had gone on holiday at the all-inclusive resort together.She is believed to have gone on holiday to escape after she and her partner broke up.The nurse said: She was so distraught this mum.She had gone on holiday to escape. She was an absolutely fantastic mum. When she was talking to everybody she was saying this has really sorted my head out coming on holiday, I realised whats important. Hes the best thing thats ever happened to me.  They moved her friend to another hotel to be nearer the hospital. The girls mum flew out yesterday.The nurse added: When we left Greece the doctor over there said basically it was a cot death.Doctors are providing the heartbroken mother with psychological support, according to local media.Reports say that she went to wake up her baby, but grew concerned when she saw he was not moving or reacting to her words.A doctor later confirmed the devastating news that the baby had died.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: indonesian tribe loved ones corpses cigarettes tradition
story: Shots of the Toraja Tribe, who live in South Sulawesi in Indonesia, capture villagers sprucing up their relatives in a bid to obtain good fortune.Images show a family lighting a cigarette hanging inside a corpse’s mouth, dressing skulls in bandanas and taking selfies with the dead bodies.There are around one million Torajan people in Indonesia, most of whom live in the South Sulawesi region. They believe that after death the soul remains in the house so the dead are treated to food, clothing, water, cigarettes.Bodies are kept wrapped in blankets in the room of the house or a ‘tongkonan’ - a traditional Torajan ancestral house with a distinctive boat-shaped roof so the rain water runs off.The fascinating snaps were captured by freelance photojournalist Hariandi Hafid show the Toraja tribe taking part in the “Manene” ritual - in which family members exhume and clean the bodies of the dead. Unlike in western cultures, where the body is swtly removed after death and frequently held a few days later, the tribe often keeps the bodies of their deceased loved ones in the family home for weeks,not months.During this time, the corpse will be spoken to in general conversation and a meal brought to the body three or four times a day.Once a funeral is held – after a suitable period of mourning and reflection – it is often a lavish affair costing exorbitant amounts of money and held over several days.The Toraja believe that death is just the next step in the soul’s journey through the universe. “My mother died suddenly, so we aren’t ready yet to let her go,” a Torajan woman, Yohana Palangda, told National Geographic in  of how this helps the grieving process.“I can’t accept burying her too quickly.”The ritual is performed during the harvest season around July, August and September and is typically performed every three or four years, depending on the familys wishes.During the procession, the traditional elderswill recite prayers in the ancient Toraja language.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: offices coronavirus testing
story: The Government will urge companies to launch a regular testing drive among their employees to help keep the economy on trackthere are spikes of coronavirus through the winter. ⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesMeetings between business leaders and Whitehall officials over how to roll out the widespread use of mobile testing units in factories and offices around the country, according to the Financial Times. Employers who have their staff regularly tested could even be allowed to stay open in the event of a local lockdown, a source told the FT. Director-general of the British Chambers of Commerce Adam Marshall said companies could embrace the idea but onlythe Government ensures the cost of tests are cheap. He said: We are supportive of the ramp-up of testingthat helps businesses avoid blanket future lockdownsA standard swab test currently costs around £ - which is out of the budget of all but the wealthiest companies such including Formula One, the Premier League and a handful of City of London businesses, who have brought in regular testing. But the speed at which testing is being developed to enable faster swab results has led to hope costs could plummet and be accessible to more companies. Acting head of the Institute of Directors Edwin Morgan said: The big question is who pays for it.If larger companies want to do it voluntarily then great. If youre a small company, and lots of them still arent in fantastic shape, then its a lot harder. Office buildings around the country have stayed empty since lockdown was introduced on March . A fresh survey of , adults from eight countries has showed that workers in the UK and the US are least likely to want toto the office. The analysis, done by ManpowerGroup, found that the main reason people didnt want to go back to the workplace was because of fears over a second wave. Around  per cent of British workers had negative feelings about ing to the office, compared to only  per cent in Germany.The PMs deputy spokesperson said yesterday workers should start asking their employers when they canto pile pressure onto bosses to get offices covid secure. He said anyone who cant work from home should have a covid secure workplace they can do their job from. Matt Hancock is preparing plans for another testing target to get national capacity to , daily testing in October, and , by January. title: 16 signs 500k coronavirus long haulers hair loss exhaustion insomnia
story: The condition, dubbed as long Covid has left many people unable to work and others are still suffering months after initially overcoming the virus.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesAround half a million Brits are believed to be suffering with long Covid after doctors dismissed long term symptoms as ME. A cross party group of MPs has now demanded that the UK government steps ups and helps people suffering from the condition.It comes just days after researchers at North Bristol NHS Trust found that  out of  patients discharged from Southmead Hospital in Bristol were still experiencing symptoms when they were invited back to the clinic.Symptoms included breathlessness, muscle aches and excessive fatigue.The key symptoms of the virus include a new and persistent cough, a high temperature and a loss of taste and smell.But what are the sixteen symptoms of long Covid and what do you need to watch out for A survey recently revealed that one in four people who have overcome the virus have since experienced hair loss.An online survey was conducted of , people who have survived Covid.The results from the Survivor Corp Facebook group found that  per cent of people had experienced some form of hair loss.This could be hair loss of the scalp, or on other parts of the body such as the eyebrows.The condition know as telogen effluvium , is when a person temporarily experiences hair loss.Doctors have said that this usually occursa patient has recently experienced a stressful situation.TE occurs when the number of the follices in the scalp changes.It usually affects the top of the scalp and in most cases the hair line will not recedesomeone experiences TE.Severe cases of TE will spread to the eyebrows and other parts of the body.A high temperature is a key symptom of the coronavirus - anything over C is considered to be a high temperature.The NHS states thatyour temperature is that high then you wont need to take it and you will feel hot to touch on your chest or on your back.Your normal body temperature is approximately C.A fever is usually when your body temperature is .C or higher. You may feel warm, cold or shivery.In babies and children a normal temp is about .C, but this can y slightly from child to child.Back in June the US added diarrhoea to its official list of symptoms. This means you are experiencing uncontrollable bowel movements.Experts at Kings College London had previously identied this as a symptom.They placed patients into six categories of severity and people in categories three and six were found to have experienced diarrhoea.This symptom can be debilitating for many and is likely to stop people ing to work.In June it was reported that many Brits were suffering with post-virus fatigue.If you are suffering from exhaustion then you will have little or no energy - leaving you unable to do every day tasks.Its also likely that you will suffer from mental and physical exhaustion as a result and many patients who have overcome the coronavirus have battled this.Kings College London also listed exhaustion in three of its symptom clusters.Coronavirus is an infection that attacks the lungs so its no surprise that people who contract the virus are likely to suffer from chest pains.Some may have also been put on a ventilator which may cause pain later on.Even though this is not an official symptom - the World Health Organisation previously warned thatyou had the virus then your chest might be tight.Many people with long Covid had reported experiencing chest pains when climbing the stairs or walking.Insomnia is a condition which means you are unable to sleep for prolonged periods of time.The All-Party Parliamentary Grouppreviously heard that people with long Covid feel pressure toto work.Insomnia can leave you with exhaustion and many would struggle to work in these conditions.During March many people also reported that they were experiencing insomnia due to the stress caused by the pandemic.Patients who have overcome the virus have said they have experienced a hallucination.A hallucination is when someone sees, hears, smells, tastes or feels things that dont exist outside their mind.They can be frightening and are often caused by medications.A study previously found that there had been a rise in patients suffering from neurological conditions - with  per cent of patients having reported neurological issues. Covid toes is mainly seen in kids, doctors say. Medics treating Covid- patients have continuously reported seeing unusual cases where people have developed blisters and purple lesions on their feet.Doctors believe that the condition is inflammatory.The condition appears on the feet of patients, even when no other symptoms are apparent.Dr Ignacio Garcia-Doval explained that the most common type of rash in the study was maculopapules - small, flat and raised red bumps.However, experts were reluctant to say that the rashes are definitely linked to Covid- as they are a common symptom of many viral infections.The European Journal of Pediatric Dermatology said there had been a epidemic of cases in Italy involving children and young adults.It is a condition that had not previously been linked to the virus - but the APPGs have now added it to the list of symptoms that people with long Covid are suffering.Experiencing chills is another symptom that people with long Covid have experienced.Chills are the feeling you get when you start to feel cold despite there being no reason for this.Chills can occur with a fever and can make you shiver and shake.It can also feel like its impossible for you to get warm.Patients who are suffering with long Covid have reported feeling disorientated with their surroundings.Many patients have reported feeling delirium, confusion and anxiety.In particular, doctors say those with severe coronavirus who are admitted to hospital often develop an acute brain condition called “ICU delirium.Now many patients with long Covid have continued to suffer from these issues.   Cognitive issues include suffering from memory loss, struggling to pay attention and finding it hard to understand others.This can be debilitating for sufferers and many with the symptom have been unable toto work.Experts said that this may be caused by direct viral infection of the brain tissue.Associate Professor of Psychology, University of Michigan, Natalie C Tronson said: Growing evidence suggests additional indirect actions triggered via the virus’s infection of epithelial cells and the cardiovascular system, or through the immune system and inflammation, contribute to lasting neurological changes after Covid-.Most people who have the coronavirus are likely to experience breathing issues as it is a condition that attacks the lungs.But once patients have recovered many are still reporting this issue.Shortness of breath feels as though you are not getting the right amount of oxygen you need.It can feel like you are struggling to catch your breath.Most people will be used to experiencing muscle or body achesthey have had a long session at the gym.But people suffering from long Covid are often experiencing these issues and are unable to do simple things like get up out of a chair without struggling.Discomfort is a symptom of most viral infections as a foreign body has entered your system and your body responds to it accordingly.Inflammation caused by Covid can aggravate the muscles.Most people will usually experience a heart rate of over  beats a minutesthey have just exericised.A normal resting heart rate for adults can be anywhere between  and  and factors like weight can also contribute to this and typically people who weigh more have higher resting heart rates.Experts have previously said that athletes who recover from the virus may face dire or lasting heart complications.Having a high heart rate can make you feel as though you are out of breath.People who have recovered from the virus and are suffering from long Covid claim that they have experienced vomiting.In China, around only  per cent of coronavirus sufferers were being sick or had nausea - compared to more common symptoms like feveror dry cough .Yet, you can not rule out vomiting as a symptom, with former Page  model and actress Linda Lusardi claiming the virus made her sick, but in a dferent colour.Now people with long Covid have warned that this is an ongoing title: we need to return high street jane moore
story: Having sex was virtually impossible, because by the time we’d removed them we had fallen asleep with exhaustion.Now, jeans come in all shapes and sizes and — hallelujah — streeeeeeetch where necessary to accommodate our lumps and bumps.However, it’s imperative to try before you buyyou want to find the perfect pair and, thanks to lockdown, I found myself shopping for jeans, and other clothes — online.The results prove why we simply mustn’t allow our struggling High Street clothes shops to vanish without trace.I’m usually a size , but am now sporting a bread-baby after lock- down so decided to play safe by ordering a size bigger. Pictured is, apparently, a pair of “size ” jeans from online giant Asosin front of my old size sI couldn’t get them up one leg and, quite frankly, Kate Moss would struggle too. So they’re going back.Then a beguiling ad for summer dresses popped up on my Instagram account and I clicked through to a site called “Cinderear” showing a wide range of very pretty frocks on tanned and shapely models.I ordered what was described as a “Printed Folding Holiday Swing Dress” in what looked like an airy cotton, cinched in at the waist with a brown leather belt. The colour was described as apricot.What arrived — several weeks later — was a beyond-hideous sartorial aberration that was “Made in China” , out of a paper-thin polyester that would make me think twice about standing near a naked flame.What’s more, the colour was more camel and blue than “apricot”, it swamped me, and the brown belt in the photo was nowhere to be seen.It cost me  — approx £ — and the s policy is so ­unintelligible that it’s not worth the bother. More fool me.Buying a bookshelf or bog brush online is fine, but clothes is another matter. I like to feel the fabric and see the fit.So a couple of weeks ago, I masked up and ventured out on a shopping trip to West London’s vast Westfield where I felt like a ­Hollywood superstar having a ­personal shopping experience. It was am on a Monday morning and virtually empty.Little wonder when the ­government guidance says retailers must “discourage customers from handling products while browsing, and keep fitting rooms closed”.One store let me try on a dress then sanitised the cubicle afterwards, another told me thatI tried something on they would have to then take it off display for  hours.In LK Bennett, the fitting rooms were closed and I askedI could try on a blouse over my clothes, just to seeit actually fits. No, they said, you have to buy the item, take it home to try it on, then bring it backit doesn’t fit. Needless to say, I ed home empty-handed.So,our High Street clothes shops are to survive the pandemic, two things need to happen.Unless classed as vulnerable, those of us who actually enjoy clothes ­shopping need to get back out there as soon as possible and actively support them. The reasons why are unclear, but Ms Marney, , says that aside from going on long walks and cosying up in country pubs, they “argued about the finer points of EU legislation”.Ah yes, that should do it.THE Duke and Duchess of Sussex will not feature in TV drama The Crown because there’s not “enough distance” from their story, says the show’s creator Peter Morgan.Also, their le is so outlandish that the series would fall under the category of reality show rather than drama.VINNIE JONES – the “hardman” of football – is seeing a psychologist three times a week after losing we Tanya to cancer.“I would recommend going to see a psychologist  per cent,” he says.“You’re not lying down on a couch asyou’re some lunatic or serial killer. Was it an escape for him alone to snatch a few hours of quiet reflection Or was it a chance for him and Carrie to have noisy sex away from the baby and ever-present bodyguards THE top dream jobs for school leavers are app or games developer and social media influencer.If kids don’t get back to school pronto, that’s all they’ll be able to do.NO ONE begrudges ­politicians a holiday – ­particularly during a ­parliamentary recess.But when you’re an Education minister, you have one job – to be around when the ordure inevitably hits the fan over A-level results being randomly downgraded by an algorithm.Yet not only did Gillian Keegan book a trip abroad, she actually posted a photo from the French Alps on results day – when countless students saw their future plans evaporate. story: The Duchess of Sussex, , met with Gloria Steinem for a garden chat about womens rights.⚠️Read our Meghan and Harry blog for the latest news on the Royal couple.In a black and white clip released on social media, Meghan expressed admiration for -year-old political activists work in fighting for gender equality and they discuss the importance of voting. Gloria welcomed the Duchess home and she replied: Thank you. Me too, for so many reasons.Meghan and Harry have refocused their activism since quitting the Royal Family and moving to the US with their son Archie.The two sat opposite one another in wooden chairs, keeping socially distant as they were separated by a table in a lush back garden. Appearing to be starstruck by the activist, Meghan gushed: People forget how hard women like youand so many others have fought for us just to be where we are right now.The author replies: If you dont vote you dont exist, it is the only place were all equal, the voting booth.Meghan says today is a pretty great day, for me its a pretty great day as they bond over their shared views. Meghan and Gloria are even joined by the Duchesss beloved dogs Pula, a black Labrador, and Guy, a beagle, as they wander into frame to sit at her feet. Gloria jokes the pooches want to be on camera.Looking laid back and relaxed, the clip is a change of pace from the video conference calls and virtual summits she has been doing amid the pandemic.The one minute  second video is a teaser for a full question and answer session which will be streamed on Wednesday.It is unclear where the clip was filmed, but the presence of the dogs may suggest it was Meghan and Prince Harrys new £million nine bedroom home in Montecito, Calornia.Gloria was one of the most prominent figures of the Women Liberations movement of the s and s.In the video, Steinem confesses that she is concerned about youth attitudes to voting.She also adds her activism work was no sacrice.What worries me the most are young people, who I understand are the least likely to vote, she saidI can understand the feeling that they dont think they have an impact, and yet its more important for them to vote because theyre going to be alive long after I am.Theyre going to be suffering the consequences... movements are families, its no sacrice.I get to do what I love and care about every day of my le, how great is that Makers have billed the QA session as a historic backyard chat as they shared the teaser clip on Twitter.LA-born Meghan has been using her  to encourage people to vote ahead of the upcoming US presidential election in November.US President Donald Trump is facing a close-run race with Democratic rival Joe Biden, with the battlelines redrawn amid the coronavirus pandemic mass protests over racism in the US.The Duchess courted controversy last week when she was a a surprise guest on Michelle Obama’s When All Women Vote event on Thursday.She appeared to take a dig at Trump, saying: We all know what’s at stake.Meghan added: “If you arent part of the solution, youre part of the problem. If you are complacent, you are complicit.”She added: This fight is worth fighting and we all have to be out there mobilising to have our voices heard.“We can make a dference in this election and we will make a dference in this election.Its not the first time that Meghan has had strong words for the US President.Meghan detailed why she didn’t like Trump in a  interview on US talk show, The Nightly Show with Larry Wilmore, ahead of his election win.She said: “It’s really the moment I go. We film Suits in Toronto and I might just stay in Canada.“Yes, of course, Trump is isive, think about female voters alone, right Trump previously called Meghan nasty over the comment during an interview with The Sun in the Oval Office. title: gold tudor coin found in field 15000
story: The “extremely rare” Queen Mary half-angel — then worth five shillings — dates from  to .It was struck for Henry VIII’s daughter Mary I, and was unearthed by a metal detectorist on farmland in Leicestershire.Valuer William Hayward said: “It’s an incredible find and in good quality for its age. “Queen Mary brought English coins back to the sterling standard.“She struck all her gold coins at the more traditional fineness of . rather than some of the debased coins made during the reign of her half-brother Edward VI and her father Henry VIII.”It will be auctioned by Hansons in Etwall, Derbys, on October .Mary I , also known as Mary Tudor, was Queen from July  until her death.She was the only child of Henry VIII by his first we, Catherine of Aragon, to survive to adulthood.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: greta thunberg returns to school after gap year of climate activism
story: The -year-old posted a photo of herself on Instagram with a schoolbag and bicycle.She told her followers on Monday it felt “so great” to be going back to classes.High schools in her native Sweden have been reopening this week.Greta first staged solo protests outside Sweden’s parliament in .Students around the globe followed her lead.Greta was invited to speak to world political and business leaders, and was twice nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize.In December , the Swedish-born activist was announced as Time Magazines  Person of the Year.She is the youngest person ever to receive the accolade at  and has become a global icon for speaking out on climate change.Greta featured on the cover of the magazine standing on a rocky shore, with splashing waves.The headline: The Power Of Youth was emblazoned on it, as was the name of the award.In the magazine, she is quoted as saying: I’d like to tell my grandchildren that we did everything we could.And we did it for them — for the generations to come.”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kim jong un chairing coronavirus emergency meeting
story: The countrys state news agency KCNA said on Wednesday Jong-un gathered the politburo to call for prevention efforts against the virus, and an impending typhoon.The meeting assessed “some defects in the state emergency anti-epidemic work for checking the inroads of the malignant virus”, KCNA said in a statement, according to Reuters.The meeting was the third high-level political conference in as many weeks, according to AP.North Korea has yet to confirm a single-case of COVID-, but outsiders have widely doubted its virus-free claimJong-un set tasks for the party and public services at every level, saying that to thoroughly prevent the casualties by the typhoon and minimize the damage to crops is important work which can never be neglected even a moment, KCNA paraphrased the leader as saying.Typhoon Bavi as of Wednesday morning was near the South Korean island of Jeju and was on course to hit the northwest coast of the Korean Peninsula around daybreak Thursday morning. South Koreas weather agency said it had a maximum wind speed of  kilometers per hourand was forecast as one of the strongest to hit the peninsula this year.During a meeting last week, the ruling party scheduled a rare congress in January to set development goals for the next five years.Experts say the coronavirus derailed some of Kims major economic goals after North Korea imposed a lockdown that signicantly reduced trade with China, its major ally and economic leline, and likely hampered its ability to mobilize its workforce.However earlier this month a South Korean official claimed Jong-un was in a coma.The -year-old has been seen in public only a handful of times since reportedly undergoing heart surgery in April.Photos released recently by North Koreas state media have shown him attending meetings with senior officials, although questions have been raised about their authenticity.Speaking to local media, Chang Song-min, a former aide to late South Korean president Kim Dae-Jung, said he believed figures within the regime were trying to conceal a decline in Kim Jong-uns health.“I assess him to be in a coma, but his le has not ended, he said.Comparisons of commercially-available satellite images with reference points in footage showing Kim on recent public outings also suggest the footage is genuine, NK News reports.Video broadcast on North Korean state media purportedly shows Kim appearing at the Sixth Plenary Meeting of the th Central Committee of the Workers’ Party of Korea on August .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: schools england masks visors boris
story: The PM suggested that a u-turn was on the cards just hours after Scotland ordered kids to wear them at school from Monday.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesTES reported that the Government is expected to make a major u-turn this afternoon - saying that masks will be worn by kids at school in communal areas.It reported that Public Health England and the DFE have signed off the move.Department for Education sources did not deny the story today.Earlier in the day Mr Johnson said the Government would always review the evidence and the advice may change.On a business visit today he told reporters: On the issue of whether or not to wear masks in some contexts - you know, well look at the the changing medical evidence as we go on.If we need to change the advice then of course we will.It comes  hours after No insisted that the Government would not be launching a fresh review after the World Health Organisation said all kids over  should wear them.Asked why the UK Government was ignoring the WHO, Mr Johnson said this lunchtime: The overwhelming priority is to get all pupils into school.If there are things we have to do to y the advice on medical grounds, we will, of course, do that.But as the chief medical officer, all our scientic advisers, have said, schools are safe.Meanwhile schools started to announce their own policies on face masks - piling pressure on the PM to change tack.The Oasis Academy chain of  schools today joined several others in saying that their pupils would have to wear masks in corridors and other communal areas to stop the spread of the virus when schoolsnext week.The chains founder, Steve Chalke, said this morning: Oasis has booked face visors  masks for all our school staff  masksfor our secondary students for transition in corridors etc.It came as Scotland confirmed that school pupils will have to wear face coverings in corridors and communal areas from next Monday.Any kids over the age of  will have to wear them on school transport from Monday too, it was confirmed today.And kids could even have to wear them in the classrooms tootheres a local outbreak -public health officials force it of the school thinks its necessary.Ms Sturgeon said today she thought it was the right thing to do.But there will be no fines for not sticking to the rules, the First Minister stressed.The Welsh Government are also set to review their evidence on face coverings in schools too.Boris Johnson is to give an online press-conference style event in the next few days to try and allay fears about theto school.No opened up the floor for questions about coronavirus online today.The Governments advice as of May , which is based on information from SAGE says: Face coverings do not need to be worn in schools.And Business SecretaryAlok Sharma said today: Throughout this process we have followed the scientists and medical advice. PHE doesn’t currently recommend face coverings in schools. The reason is pupils and staff mix in consistent groups.We are always considering the latest advice and evidence.Headteachers are today calling on the Government to review their face masks advice ahead of schools .The Association of School and College leaders said today there was a lack of clarity on the issue.And Director of Public Health for Gateshead, Alice Wiseman, said she wouldreview the issue with local heads.It is my intention to have a broad discussion with teachers in Gateshead to see what would work best for them and their parents, she told Radio  today.We need to make sure they are not used as an alternative for the most effective prevention measure, such as social distancing.Former Education Secretary Justine Greening said this morning the Government should at least consider the matter.She told the BBC: It is something ministers and gov should consider.It just seems a sensible potential step that should be looked at.It is one of the things that can be considered to not only put confidence back into a system that badly needs it but to be another step that can help reduce risks.Scottish and Northern Irish schools have already gone back, and pupils in England willto classrooms from next week.But yesterday the Government insisted that it would not look again at face masks for kids in schools - despite a World Health Organisation recommendation that over s should wear them.No insisted that masks in schools would harm kids learning - and there were no plans to look again at the advice.Gavin Williamson slapped down Nicola Sturgeons demands for coverings - and said there was no evidence children should have to wear masks on top of the social distancing policies that are going to be in place.Children are placed in social bubbles of their classes and have to stay m away from their teachers when theyto the classroom.Mr Williamson said last night: Were not in a position where we are suggesting [masks for schoolchildren] because we think there is a system of controls, that are in place in all schools, for children to be able tosafely and for staff to be able tosafely.At the moment kids under the age of  dont have to wear them at all across the UK.But those over  have to wear them like adults do in shops and on public transport.At the moment its up to inidual schools and headsthey want to enforce mask-wearing - with a handful choosing to do so.Ms Sturgeon has said kids can wear them in classroomsthey want to.She told the daily coronavirus briefing yesterday: Were consulting on this specic measure because, firstly, mixing between dferent groups is more likely in corridors and communal areas - increasing the potential for transmission.Secondly, crowding and close contact in these areas is more likely and voices could be raised, resulting in greater potential for creating aerosol transmission.Finally, theres also less scope for ventilation in these areas.A Number  spokesman said: There are no plans to review the guidance on face coverings in schools.We are conscious of the fact that it would obstruct communication between teachers and pupils.I dont think the WHO guidance refers specically to whether a child over  should wear a mask in school.The Department of Education said that masks were not necessary as other measures were in place - such as bubbles and extra cleaning.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pubs could be ordered to shut birmingham
story: The City Council today revealed tough new powers to try and stop the city from going into a full lockdown.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesIt means police will be able to stop people going in restaurants or bars which arent covid-secure.And some large events such as weddings and funerals could be cancelled too.Cops will also have the power to shutdown raves at outdoor spaces too.The measures are partly to stop the spread of the virus so that schools dont have to shut and kids education wont be harmed any further, leaders said today.It comes after a Gold Command meeting with Matt Hancock and local leaders in Birmingham last week.The city became an area of concern and will now become an area of enhanced support after a spike in cases.However, sources in Birmingham told The Sun today that rates of infection have been going down over recent days and the panic in government is starting to calm.Last week it was reported that cases had reached  per , in the last week. This compared to Oldham - which is under tighter lockdown rules - and had a high of  per , earlier this month.Last week they were told not to meet ANYONE outside their household to stop the bug spreading further.However, local leaders are still mulling whether to slap on extra restrictions on Birmingham residentsthe numbers dont go the right way.West Midlands Mayor Andy Street said today: Given the illegal raves and some premises not complying with track and trace, this tightening of powers is the right move.However talks with Government are still ongoing, andwe want to avoid new restrictions we need everyone to stick to the rules.The news also comes as cops broke up SEVENTY illegal parties in Brum last weekend despite the threat of tighter measures, and the raves are thought to be a contributing factor to the ongoing case numbers.Younger people and people going out to work are forming the bulk of new cases in the city.But police across the UK will have the power to slap ravers with £, fines for hosting illegal parties from this week.Councillor Ian Ward, Leader of Birmingham City Council said today: “While the recent figures show our rates are going down, we cannot be complacent.We must all continue to follow all the relevant safety guidance in order to protect our families, friends and work colleagues. Most importantly staying disciplined now is a price worth paying when compared to the cost of damaging the future le chances of our City’s children – which may happenthere is a spike in the rate of infections and schools have to close, or parents do not send them due to concerns about the potential risks . story: NewsopinionKey worker heroes saved the country - now lets give them the power to rebuild itThey have risen to this unprecedented challenge and put their lives on the line to keep our country goingShareCommentsByAngela Rayner:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsopinionKey workers are ideally placed to rebuild our communities and our country " %, rgba, rgba, url"What is really going on in politics  Get our daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailOur key worker heroes have been on the frontline working round the clock to get us through this crisis. They have risen to this unprecedented challenge and put their lives on the line to keep our country going. Now we need them to help lead the recovery from this crisis as we build back better. NHS and social workers, bus drivers, posties, delivery drivers, shop workers, and so many others have made sure we have all been cared for, fed and connected during this pandemic. They are ideally suited to rebuilding our communities and our country in the months and years ahead. The last few months have proven beyond all doubt that it is the unsung, underpaid and undervalued workers who are the backbones of our communities – the people that our economy and our country cannotwithout. They know what their communities need and truly know what it means to be a ‘public servant’. We want to ensure that our key workers are at the heart of decision-making across the country, which is why we are encouraging and supporting those who want to get involved in politics and stand for election in the years ahead. Politics is not arcane parliamentary language of Statutory Instruments or Select Committees. Politics is about what is happening on your high street, in your town, at your workplace. Politics is about making sure your children’s school has got the resources it needs or fighting back against dodgy landlords ripping off tenants. Real people and real lives. It is clear for all to see that our political institutions do not reflect the communities that they serve. I am proud that before I became a Member of Parliament I worked in our social care sector, going from house to house in my community supporting those who needed help. But when MPs talk in the House of Commons about the crisis facing our social care sector, how many of them have worked on the frontline and have first-hand experience of it  During debates on the Budget or the economy how many MPs have fed their families on a minimum wage pay packet  Not many, and certainly not nearly enough. This needs to change, and I am determined that the Labour Party, working with our trade unions and colleagues in local government, will lead that change.  I am proud that the Parliamentary Labour Party is the most erse it has ever been and is more than half of Labour MPs are women for the first time in our history. But we all know there is a huge amount of work to do, at all levels of government. We need to do more to ensure that our political institutions and elected representatives are rooted in our communities and better represent and reflect our communities, in all of their ersity. As deputy leader and party chair I am leading initiatives to encourage and support more female, black, Asian and minority ethnic, disabled and LGBTQ+ members to put themselves forward to stand as candidates and run for office. Now our Party and our movement will also be working to identy and support key workers who want to champion their community.

The scaffolding supervisor has terminal cancer after a potentially le-saving operation was cancelled because of Covid. Our hearts go out to Adrian and his family. title: mum diagnosed 5 tumours after
story: NewsMum diagnosed with  tumours after Specsavers eye test shows off DIY home transformationEXCLUSIVE: Sharon Coupe was diagnosed with stage four bowel cancer following a routine eye test but says there’s no need to let things go just because of cancer’ and has completed an inspiring DIY makeover on her homeShareCommentsByTfany WallisJoseph WilkesReporter:,  AUG NewsSharon Coupe was diagnosed with cancer in May  after an eye test " %, rgba, rgba, url"News, views and top stories . Dont miss our must-read newsletterWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA mother who was diagnosed with cancer after a routine eye check at Specsavers has revealed her stunning DIY home transformation. Sharon Coupe, , from Edwinstowe near Sherwood Forest has always been house proud but felt like she stopped caring about her home after her diagnosis in May . The mother-of-two’s best friend was determined to help her with a DIY makeover and the two of them have spent lockdown making her home beautul again. Sharon, who has stage four bowel cancer and five tumours, said she believes there is no need to let things go just because of having cancer. She said: My house has always been beautul, but when I got diagnosed I just felt like I didn’t care what the house looked like anymore. If I was to die, nobody would say aposoh she had a lovely houseapos. But Cathie has dragged me out of my rut. We are now steadily going through the house and making it beautul again. In May , Sharon was rushed to Kings Mill Hospital in Nottinghamshire the same day as having her eyes tested after the optician saw something behind her eye that was illuminating. She was referred as an ‘urgent casualty’ before being told she would need to go to Hallamshire hospital in Sheffield. Two weeks later, the support worker was told she had a tumour behind her eye and needed to undergo a ciliary flap biopsy - she had the procedure on th August . One week later, doctors confirmed the cancerous tumour behind her right eye as secondary. Sharon, who is mother to Connor, , and Aaron, , then underwent a series of tests to find the primary cancer. Sharon said:I asked the doctors not to sugar coat anything for me. But my heart sank - I had silent tears rolling down my face and all I could think of was my boys Connor and Aaron. I bought them up alone as when Connor was five, his dad and I separated but I found out I was nine weeks pregnant with Aaron. My boys are my absolute rocks.  I provided a -hour urine sample, had numerous head, shoulder and full body scans before being sent to the Western Park hospital. I also had two liver biopsies and had to stay in hospital for five nights. The results delivered the devastating news that the primary cancer was in Sharon’s bowel - but it had also spread to her liver, lungs, right eye and bones - finding five tumours in total. She was told it is an extremely rare cancer which is inoperable and incurable but hopefully treatable. Her best friend Cathie and her mother were both by Sharon’s side as the results were given to her. Sharon added: Once the professor said the primary was in my lower bowel, I askedit could be removed but he said “that’s not all” as he explained the five tumours.  The professor said in his  years of experience - he had only seen three patients with this rare cancer - Sharon being his third. Sharon hasn’t been given a timeline but says she is now stage four. In July, she underwent an MRI scan and more PET scans. The last ones had shown treatment had been successful as  of the  tumours are stable. However the tumour behind her eye is not stable - and it has grown, with a cataract over it. She recently found out that the characteristics of the tumour had changed indicating it could have spread to her brain.  She said: As for the eye - I have now been told regardlessit’s gone into my brain I have to have the eye removed as the tumour is pushing on the retina. The cancer has also spread to my skull, collar bones, manubrium, my hips, my pelvis, my spine and three disks. The results of these new scans can show even more but we have to wait and see. The-mother-of-two felt like she stopped caring about her home after she was diagnosed - despite previously being described as ‘house proud’. But the best friends have now been completing a DIY home makeover. Sharon believes there is no need to let things go just because of cancer but said she has noticed DIY work taking a lot longer due to the fatigue that comes with the disease.  She said: There’s no need at all to let things go just because you have cancer… Yes it’s taking a lot longer to do as the fatigue that comes with this disease is something you cannot describe. But we are doing this and we are getting there! We are doing one room at a time but it takes a while as I do all the wallpaper, I am up and down the ladders, Cathie has been painting and I’ve glossed all the doors.Sharon experiences horrendous fatigue and extreme side effects from treatments including hot flushes, temperature, sweating, aching and headaches.She has also had pain in her hips and lower back throughout the DIY work.  Sharon has morphine inside her   and believes she wouldnapost be able to she didn’t have the constant pain relief. Sharon is on sandostatin LAR which is injected into her buttocks muscle every three weeks. She also has an injection in her stomach every eight weeks for her bone cancer but now suffers from extremely sensitive teeth. She added: I have Calci D mg a day, docusate and senna to help with the bowel, Creon  to help with my stomach and oxy norm every  hours for pain. I am on antidepressants too as the professor said as strong as I am and as much as I am smiling whenever they see me, he thinks this will take its toll.  He said it is a lot for any one person to put up with and I now have counselling too. However the pains and medication hasn’t stopped Sharon. The best friends have been working through the house transforming one room at a time. Sharon’s bedroom cost £ and is now complete with flamingo wallpaper and pink bedding and curtains. Her bedroom took three months to complete as Sharon struggled to do the wallpapering and go up and down ladders.  The friends then moved onto another bedroom which Sharon wanted to make grey, black and silver. This was done during lockdown and took five weeks. Sharon and Cathie worked on the bedroom with the help of her two sons and a family friend Les - the transformation cost £. She said: I think the room looks so classy now. All of these rooms have been done during lockdown. I can honestly say I am loving doing all of this. It may take its toll by the end of the day and it may take longer but when it’s done the feeling I get is of great joy knowing I’ve made an effort and not just stayed in bed feeling sorry for myself all day.  Sharon has also been keeping her friends and family updated via social media and said she has been overwhelmed by the support and generosity of people. She has had ’s of cards, flowers, gts and hampers and feels there are so many people that have gone out of their way and above and beyond to support her.The mother said she gets kind messages everyday from people asking hershe needs help and said she had no idea people on Facebook were so kind and caring.However Sharon recently experienced a breakdown and her two sons surprised her by taking her to the garden. Connor and Aaron surprised their mum by pulling all the weeds up, turfing the lawn and creating a decking area with a patio for her. Her friend Cathie also planted lots of flowers and even got Sharon a sunlounger to cheer her up. She said: Connor and Aaron came to my room after three weeks of breaking down and said aposright come on mum - let’s get you up.apos They took me to my dump of a back garden and when they said open your eyes - I was amazed! My garden was beautul and it really did help and prompted me to get up and sort myself out. Sadly money hasn’t been easy for Sharon as she only qualied for statutory sick pay - having not been in her job long enough.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA policeman has been sacked after he offered to have sex in his squad car with a woman who said she aposliked unormsapos on her dating app profile. Former PC Andy Ross was dismissed after a hearing found that he breached professional standards by wooing the woman. It was said that the Wiltshire Police officer even told her what to doanyone saw them together - such as pretending she had lost her dog. The inquiry heard that PC Ross contacted the woman - known as Ms X - last year after noticing her profile online, where she said she liked unorms. He sent a picture of himself in unorm to prove he was a police officer before using his personal mobile to arrange to meet her. PC Ross, , and Ms X then met at around pm on June  after he drove to her house in a marked car - at her request. He picked her up in the vehicle and parked up in an isolated location, where they chatted, kissed and hugged. The couple also talked about what Ms X would sayanyone spotted her with a police officer, it was said. PC Ross suggested she could say she’d lost her dog and he was helping her look for it. Seven weeks later, while on duty, the officer swapped a series of raunchy messages with the woman - including suggesting they could have sex in his police car. He then picked her up from home at .pm on August  while on duty in Chippenham, Wilts., and drove to an isolated location. They parked up for ten minutes, chatted, kissed and hugged. He dropped her off at home at around .pm. Again, they talked about what she would sayanyone asked. PC Ross suggested she say she had gone to the police station to make a witness statement and even fetched a witness information notice from the boot of his car to aid the lie. Barrister Alice Meredith, for Wiltshire Police, said the constable’s actions had brought discredit on the police service and would have undermined people’s confidence in the force. He was accused of neglecting his responsibilities as a police officer and breached a specic point in the force’s code of conduct stopping officers from engaging in sexual conduct or inappropriate behaviour while on duty. She said: The officer wished to meet with Ms X having been interacting with her on a dating website. Having expressed an interest in unorms and, prior to the second meeting, discussed engaging in sexual activity involving the use of a police car, Ms X and the officer made arrangements to meet whilst the officer was on unormed duty and using a marked police vehicle. The officer sent a photograph of a marked police vehicle he was driving, drove near her home in that vehicle and then collected her and met with her in that vehicle whilst on unormed duty.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailOne in five cash-strapped adults have no idea how much debt they’re in – and they don’t want to know either. A poll of , adults found  per cent would rather not find out the exact figure they owe, and  per cent don’t want to worry about something they feel they can’t do anything about. A further  per cent don’t even bother checking their account on payday, because seeing it all fly straight out to pay the bills and debt brings them down. It also emerged one in four are more likely to worry about their physical fitness than their financial form, despite six in  adults often thinking about or fretting about money. Maitham Mohsin, head of savings at Skipton Building Society, which commissioned the research, said: “We all deal with financial stress dferently. “Some of us will face it head on while others find it a challenging problem to face which can lead to some of us choosing to ignore the problem. “It’s interesting to see just how many people don’t know how much they owe or how much they have, hoping that the problem will resolve itself. “We understand things can be overwhelming but it’s important to start addressing our financial well-being as much as it is our physical and mental health where there has been such focus in recent months. If the problem is left alone it’s likely to get worse and impact on other aspects of le.” The study also found  per cent donapost check their bank balance on payday as they simply can’t be bothered to look. A further  per cent don’t check because they assume their employer won’t make a mistake, while one in  don’t even know how to access or get hold of their payslip in the first place.  And a tenth get disheartened by the amount of tax deducted from their gross salary. It also emerged more than one in  rarely check their account balance before making a purchase, but  per cent have had their card declined for not having enough left in their bank or building society. As many as  per cent have even been caught so off guard with their spending habits that they’ve been unable to afford an unexpected bill. However,  per cent wouldn’t dream of making a purchase without first checking how much they have squirreled away. The research, conducted via OnePoll, also found three-fths won’t bother to log their personal day-to-day spending. But of the  per cent who do watch their pounds and pennies, three in  use a banking app to keep track, while  per cent jot it down with a good, old fashioned pen and paper.  It also emerged nearly half of those polled hate talking about money and their finances, while  per cent don’t even like to think about it. And more than a quarter admitted to having a ‘bury their head in the sand’ attitude towards their cash situation. As a result,  per cent are worried about the current state of their finances, and three in  are even concerned for their financial future because they don’t feel they have everything in order.

Instead of a one-size-fits-all approach to social distancing, there should be graded recommendations for dferent distancing rules in dferent settings, they argued. Meanwhile they argue that much of the research is based on droplet size without accounting for exhaled air. In reality transmission is much more complex, they wrote.
